content.title: Vitamin K Deficiency Coagulopathy
content.summary: Vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy by impairing synthesis of functional vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and anticoagulant proteins (protein C, S). Vitamin K is required for γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues, enabling these factors to bind calcium and phospholipid surfaces. Causes include dietary deficiency, malabsorption, antibiotic suppression of gut flora, and warfarin therapy. Laboratory findings show prolonged PT (first), then PTT; treatment is vitamin K replacement, with urgency determining route and concurrent FFP/PCC for active bleeding.
key_points: Vitamin K-dependent factors: II, VII, IX, X, protein C, protein S
PT prolonged first (factor VII has shortest half-life ~6 hours)
Common causes: malabsorption, antibiotics, dietary deficiency, warfarin
Newborns at risk: hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (VKDB)
Treatment: Vitamin K (oral, IV, or IM); FFP or PCC for urgent reversal
PT corrects within 12-24 hours with vitamin K; faster with FFP/PCC
content.statement: Vitamin K deficiency coagulopathy results from inadequate γ-carboxylation of vitamin K-dependent factors (II, VII, IX, X, proteins C and S), presenting with prolonged PT before PTT, and treated with vitamin K replacement and blood products for active bleeding.

explanation.intuition: Vitamin K acts like a 'finishing step' in making clotting factors work. Without it, the liver produces non-functional factors that can't bind calcium properly. Factor VII dies first (shortest half-life), so PT rises before PTT.
explanation.key_insight: The sequence matters: PT prolonged BEFORE PTT because factor VII (extrinsic pathway, measured by PT) has the shortest half-life (~6 hours). Factor II has the longest half-life (~60 hours). This temporal pattern helps distinguish vitamin K deficiency from liver disease.
explanation.technical_details: Vitamin K is a cofactor for γ-glutamyl carboxylase, which converts glutamic acid residues to γ-carboxyglutamic acid (Gla) on vitamin K-dependent proteins. Gla residues are essential for calcium binding and phospholipid surface interaction. Vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKORC1) recycles vitamin K; warfarin inhibits VKORC1.

definitions_glossary.vitamin_K: Fat-soluble vitamin essential for γ-carboxylation of clotting factors
definitions_glossary.gamma_carboxylation: Post-translational modification adding carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues
definitions_glossary.vitamin_K_dependent_factors: Factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S requiring vitamin K for function
definitions_glossary.VKORC1: Vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1; target of warfarin
definitions_glossary.Gla_domain: γ-carboxyglutamic acid-rich domain required for calcium/phospholipid binding
definitions_glossary.hemorrhagic_disease_newborn: VKDB; vitamin K deficiency bleeding in neonates
definitions_glossary.PIVKA: Proteins induced by vitamin K absence; non-functional clotting factors
definitions_glossary.phytonadione: Vitamin K1; the form used therapeutically
definitions_glossary.menaquinone: Vitamin K2; produced by intestinal bacteria
definitions_glossary.PCC: Prothrombin complex concentrate; contains factors II, VII, IX, X
definitions_glossary.FFP: Fresh frozen plasma; contains all clotting factors
definitions_glossary.malabsorption: Impaired intestinal absorption of nutrients including vitamin K

sources.storage: Limited hepatic stores; depletion in 1-2 weeks without intake

vitamin_K_metabolism.absorption: Requires bile salts and pancreatic enzymes (fat-soluble)
vitamin_K_metabolism.recycling: VKORC1 regenerates reduced vitamin K from epoxide form

mechanism_of_coagulopathy.normal_function: Vitamin K enables γ-carboxylation of Glu residues → Gla residues
mechanism_of_coagulopathy.deficiency_result: PIVKA proteins produced; cannot bind Ca²⁺ or phospholipids

dietary_deficiency.timeline: Develops over 1-3 weeks if no intake

malabsorption.biliary_obstruction: Cholestasis, biliary atresia (no bile salts for absorption)

antibiotic_use.mechanism: Suppresses gut flora producing vitamin K2

causes.warfarin_therapy: Intentional VKORC1 inhibition; supratherapeutic doses cause bleeding

newborns.prevention: Routine vitamin K injection at birth

coagulation_tests.PTT: Prolonged later (factors IX, X, II involved)

specific_tests.factor_levels: Low II, VII, IX, X activity
specific_tests.mixing_study: Corrects with normal plasma (factor deficiency, not inhibitor)

distinguishing_features.vs_liver_disease: Vitamin K corrects deficiency but not liver disease (factor V normal in vitamin K deficiency)
distinguishing_features.factor_V_test: Normal in vitamin K deficiency; low in liver disease

differential_diagnosis: Liver disease coagulopathy (factor V also low; doesn't correct with vitamin K)
Acquired factor inhibitor (mixing study doesn't correct)

oral.indication: Non-urgent, mild prolongation, able to absorb

subcutaneous_IM.indication: Alternative to IV; avoid IM in severe coagulopathy

prevention_in_newborns.standard: Vitamin K 1 mg IM at birth
prevention_in_newborns.alternative: Oral vitamin K (less reliable, requires multiple doses)

definition.@value: Coagulopathy resulting from inadequate vitamin K for γ-carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S

scopeNote.@value: PT prolonged before PTT due to factor VII shortest half-life

learning_objectives: Explain the role of vitamin K in coagulation factor synthesis
Identify causes of vitamin K deficiency
Interpret coagulation studies showing vitamin K deficiency pattern
Differentiate vitamin K deficiency from liver disease
Select appropriate vitamin K replacement route and dose
clinical_pearls: PT prolonged FIRST because factor VII has shortest half-life (~6 hours)
Factor V is NORMAL in vitamin K deficiency but LOW in liver disease
Vitamin K correction takes 6-24 hours; use FFP/PCC for urgent bleeding
Newborns get routine vitamin K injection to prevent VKDB
Antibiotics that suppress gut flora can precipitate deficiency
common_misconceptions: Vitamin K deficiency only affects PT - also affects PTT (factors IX, X, II)
Oral vitamin K works immediately - takes 24-48 hours to see effect
Liver disease and vitamin K deficiency are the same - factor V distinguishes them

citations.authors: Shearer MJ, Fu X, Booth SL
citations.title: Vitamin K Nutrition, Metabolism, and Requirements

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
UpToDate. Vitamin K and the synthesis and function of Gla proteins. 2024.
